From the point of view of that person in the rocket ship, it's the other guy, his twin on the planet, who is doing the traveling away, and the changing-of-direction, and finally the returning to the start. At the heart of the apparent paradox is the fact that each point of view is the same, and yet the age difference at the end suggests otherwise there is a difference.

And there is.

The reason the guy in the rocket ship is correctly seen as the traveler, whereas the guy on the planet must be treated as the stayer-at-home is because the guy in the rocket travels relative not just to his twin, but also to THE ENTIRE REST OF THE UNIVERSE. It is that which means that when the rocket ship guy does his change-of-direction, he actually changes from one intertial reference frame to another, while his twin back home never leaves his starting inertial frame.

And it's also why the rocket ship guy will feel the "forces" associated with his turnaround -- face getting all squished, breathing becoming a bit harder, etc -- while his twin back on Earth will not.

But then that gets us to a part of the puzzle I have not yet been able to understand. The above explanation is not part of Special Relativity. It is part of General Relativity. So how come it's typically taught only in the context of the former? Or, put it another way, the Twins Paradox really is a bona fide paradox if you consider it only in the context of SR.
